Distance and Measurement**: The Pythagorean Theorem provides an efficient way to calculate distances between points in a coordinate plane or Cartesian space.
Calculation of length:** The theorem provides a simple, to calculate the length of the hypotenuse () of a right-angled triangle, given the lengths of its two smaller sides ().

Relationship between sides:**
The Pythagorean Theorem (PT) establishes a critical connection between the lengths of the sides of a right-angled triangle:
`a^2 + b^2 = c^2`, where `a` and `b` are the legs (short sides) opposite to angles A and B, respectively, in the triangle ΔABC,
while `c` is the hypotenuse (the diagonal or longest side), facing angle C (90°/-right angle).
Computing hypotenuse lengths:** The Pythagorean Theorem allows you to calculate the length of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) in a right-triangular configuration.

Calculate Hypotenuse**: The theorem allows us to easily calculate the length of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) in a right-angled triangle using the lengths of the other two sides ( legs).
This formula: c² = a² + b² (where c is the hypotenuse, and a and b are the legs), simplifies calculations dramatically.
